security: Revealing details of CIA operations, contact methods, and personnel could compromise ongoing operations and endanger individuals. The document contains information on Soviet operations, espionage activities, and the Legal Travellers Program, disclosure of which could expose intelligence-gathering techniques and sources. For example, it states, "Casasin explained the cryptonym REDWOOD as clandestine operations...separate from the REDCAP program, which was operation against Soviets outside of the USSR."
summary: An interview with Thomas Casasin, a retired CIA officer, conducted in August 1978, discussing his knowledge of Lee Harvey Oswald, Soviet operations, and CIA activities in the 1950s and 1960s.
summary_one_paragraph: In August 1978, Surell Brady interviewed retired CIA officer Thomas Casasin in Paris, France, regarding his knowledge of Lee Harvey Oswald and his past CIA activities. Casasin detailed his work in Soviet operations, including espionage and psychological warfare, his time as Chief of the Soviet Base of the North Asia Command in Japan, and his recollections of a memo he wrote in 1963 regarding Oswald's time in the Soviet Union. He also discussed the Legal Travellers Program, CIA interest in Minsk, and his assessment that Oswald was likely not a CIA operative but could have been a "lay-low" Soviet operative.
title: Interview of Thomas Casasin
conspiracy: Casasin expresses his opinion that it's inconceivable Oswald was a CIA operative but doesn't preclude the possibility Oswald was a 'lay-low' Soviet operative.
